TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: We are currently in the fourth year of the decade of landcare. As the Senate knows, the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs has started an inquiry into landcare. Submissions we have received and evidence that we have taken certainly indicate a high level of awareness of what landcare is all about and what the organisation aims to achieve.

PARA.TAB: Landcare Australia is a non-profit company established in October 1989 as part of the strategy of the decade of landcare. It receives administrative funding of about $700,000 from the federal government. Otherwise, it seeks outside assistance. The report clearly sets out the company's objectives. Before I talk about the company's objectives, we should pay a tribute to Rick Farley from the NFF and Philip Toyne from the ACF for the work that they did in increasing awareness, through both the farming communities and the ACF, so that these can work together in the decade of landcare. I think that has been one of the big achievements.

The evidence that they gave us earlier this week, which was public evidence, would make good reading for all those people who are interested in looking after our heritage, which is basically the land. If we do not look after it, we will not have our productive resources for the future.

The objectives to develop a landcare ethic amongst all Australians are very admirable and very important to encourage and stimulate public awareness of the importance of landcare and the adoption of landcare principles, to encourage and stimulate public participation in landcare activities, to encourage and facilitate education on landcare principles in schools and the community generally, and to educate and disseminate all forms of information through all media to promote the objects of the company.

I think that is important to note while we are talking about landcare tonight. Quite a few people wish to speak about it. I know Senator Sandy Macdonald, my colleague from New South Wales, wishes to speak about it, and I imagine Senator Crane and others do as well.

Landcare's object is also to develop activities to attract corporate and community funding to appropriate projects consistent with the objects of the company and to distribute funds to appropriate projects consistent with the objects of the company.

If we look at subsequent pages of the report we see clear evidence that it is meeting those objectives. Sponsorship, for example, has grown from $461 million in 1991-92 to $838 million in 1992-93. Awareness campaigns are having an impact. Surveys suggest that nearly 50 per cent of all Australians—35 per cent in the city and 60 per cent in the country—know what landcare is all about.

The most outstanding thing about the awareness campaigns undertaken by Landcare Australia is that they are showing that looking after our land—air, water and soil—is the responsibility of everyone. Promotions undertaken include involvement of companies like Uncle Toby's, raffles involving the Ford Motor Company, a school video competition and a new water quality 50c coin launch. These are the sorts of activities we need in order to educate Australians, particularly in cities, about the importance of caring for our environment.

Landcare activities now come in many various formal and informal programs. In New South Wales, landcare groups have grown from 340 in 1992 to over 500 by July 1993. That sort of expansion is happening across Australia. I pay tribute to Jim McDonald from my area on the Liverpool plains who has done such a fantastic job for the landcare movement in the area. But funds are not keeping up with demand and there is a great risk that the enthusiasm that has been created by all this promotion will fade and pass if funds are not forthcoming.

Evidence given to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs yesterday showed that while the federal government uses a figure of $105 million when referring to environment/landcare type works, the more accurate figure is under $5 million. That is not much to spread across all the worthwhile projects in Australia. When we consider that was the initial amount spent on establishing the gardens around Parliament House, we realise just how inadequate that amount must be for the whole of Australia. I commend the Landcare Australia annual report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make three points with regard to the annual report of Landcare Australia. Firstly, I congratulate the Landcare organisation and its thousands of supporters around our country. In my home state of Tasmania there are 100 groups and they are divided equally between the rural and urban areas. The problem of soil degradation is a real problem. Indeed, as an environmental issue, it is far greater than issues such as whether a certain river ought to be dammed or the harvesting of forests.

PARA.TAB: Landcare has raised the consciousness of Australians about our soil and its importance to economic and national survival. One of the great strengths of Landcare is its non-political nature and its desire to get the job done. However, this non-political role of Landcare is being brought into question, and I will deal with that later. The sponsorship from the private sector of approximately $3.5 million is a tremendous result and a wonderful example of government, companies and the community working together to achieve a genuine goal for our country—the preservation of our valuable soils.

The second point I wish to make is to sound a warning to the Landcare organisation not to become too bureaucratic. Its strength has been the fact that it has been based on local groups with local input, and local state assessment bodies. I trust this will continue to be the basis on which Landcare operates.

The third and final point—indeed, the most serious point—I wish to raise is the prostitution of this wonderful scheme for cheap political purposes. It is no surprise that the person administering the scheme was the former minister, Ros Kelly, who will be eulogised for sports rorts. Similarly, the landcare program was prostituted by the federal government. It is sad that a wholesome project such as landcare can be sullied by the filthy political handling of the Labor Party. Indeed, before the last federal election, I have reason to believe that the minister overrode the selection decisions in one state to give preference to schemes in marginal Labor seats.

Since the election, the blatant politicking has continued. I refer to the East Tamar landcare group in my own state of Tasmania. It submitted a proposal and was duly accepted by the Tasmanian selection panel and approved by Canberra. The private landowner was therefore given the green light, so to speak, and spent $4,500 of private funds on tree planting and assisting in soil preservation. Those funds, spent out of an overdraft account, were employed on the reasonable expectation that reimbursement would soon be forthcoming to the tune of approximately $2,000.

The landcare group waited for its funds and they were not received. After many weeks the person concerned, a Mr Ian Sauer, rang Canberra to be told the moneys had been sent to Silvia Smith, the very short-term member for Bass, some six weeks previously. On inquiring why the money was sent to Mrs Smith, Mr Sauer was advised that a ministerial directive had been given that, in certain cases, the cheques ought to be forwarded to the federal Labor member for presentation. Mr Sauer's cheque had been forwarded six weeks earlier to Silvia Smith's office. For the purposes of political grandstanding, the Labor Party was withholding moneys rightfully the property of other people. Mrs Smith was unavailable to make the presentation immediately because she was swanning around overseas.

The withholding of funds causes embarrassment for landowners because their cash flow is unduly affected and leads to unnecessary interest bills being paid on overdrafts. Unfortunately, the East Tamar group was not an isolated example. The federal member for Bass, Mrs Smith, and the federal member for Lyons, Mr Adams, have both engaged in this scheme.

In conclusion, I support landcare. I salute it as a project worthy of support and continued funding because of its real benefit to our environment and the educative role it plays. It is regrettable that the Labor Party cannot leave its filthy fingers off the program. As we read today in the Australian, it appears that prostitution is part of the way of life for the Australian Labor Party. That is for them, but it is a tragedy when programs such as landcare fall victim to Labor's tactics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion that the Senate take note of the fourth annual report of Landcare Australia. It is a great pleasure to follow Senator David Brownhill who, as a working farmer on the Liverpool plains west of Quirindi, would be an exponent of farming best practice as far as landcare is concerned. It is also worth noting that his son David for some years was the Landcare officer at Inverell—which is not too far away from us—and he did a very good job there.

PARA.TAB: We are nearly half way through the inaugural decade of landcare that Landcare Australia was set up to promote. Its aim was sustainable land use. The core aim of Landcare is the development of a partnership between governments—both the Commonwealth and the states—and the community, which includes particularly the National Farmers Federation. The aim is to address land degradation across this wide brown land.

Landcare's other important role is to work with the corporate sector to raise funding to support landcare group activity and conduct awareness campaigns. A large number of companies now provide sponsorship for landcare initiatives across Australia through the encouragement of Landcare Australia.

Importantly, by accepting landcare groups' projects as its own, Landcare Australia is able to offer tax deductions for any donations of money or property. Landcare Australia relies heavily on the landcare network for support in carrying out its awareness and fundraising functions, particularly for national events such as landcare month, which was held in March this year, and landcare day, which is held early in November every year.

Landcare is maintained in its effort by an extensive regional and community group network across Australia. Those of us in rural and regional Australia are all very conscious of the good work that Landcare does. Landcare Australia is to be congratulated on its ability to raise public awareness of its work. Under the heading `national awareness' the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Research conducted by the Roy Morgan Research Centre on the company's behalf, shows that between July 1991 and November 1992, the awareness of landcare doubled from 22% to 44% on a national basis, and increased threefold from 10% to 34% in capital cities.
That is quite a remarkable increase in public awareness, and Landcare Australia can take a lot of the credit for that increase.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make special mention on this occasion of the Liverpool plains land management committee, which has accepted the role of coordinating the planning, research, implementing, monitoring and evaluation of the rich Liverpool plains in New South Wales. It is an area of immense economic and farming significance and produces in excess of $120 million of export income a year.

Much of the agriculture producing this income is now being threatened by salinity and other landcare problems. Opening a recent meeting of the Liverpool plains land management committee, the chairman—a Quirindi district farmer, Jim McDonald—said that the research should be appropriate and relevant to the body providing funds and to the clients. The meeting identified two essential areas of funding—hydrological mapping and water balanced modelling. The committee is to be congratulated on its landcare initiatives. I also commend Landcare Australia to each and every Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to make some comments on the Landcare report and endorse the comments of my colleagues. Tonight I want to deal with a particular individual named in the report, Mr Elton Butcher, who received the Order of Australia for his services for land conservation. He retired on 30 June 1993 after many years as the chairman of the national soil conservation committee in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I first met Elton Butcher in the late 1960s or 1970s. As a very young person I got involved in agropolitics. He had an outstanding career serving agriculture and the meat industry—I see Senator McMullan smiling, maybe he had the joys of knowing Elton Butcher. Many people claim to be the fathers of the Landcare program, but back in the late 1960s, 1970s and into the 1980s, Elton Butcher went out and argued the case for land conservation and proper development plans at a time when it was not fashionable to do it—at a time when almost everybody said that, once people walk through the gates of the land or the farm or onto the reserve, it was sacred country and nobody had any rights to preserve that particular resource.

Elton Butcher was joined by a few other people—Harry Whittington, the promoter of interceptor banks; Graham Robertson, who was the commissioner for soil conservation for many years in Western Australia; Des O'Connell; Bill Meier; and others—who created an awareness of the importance of soil conservation, land management, on-farm and forest plantations and a whole range of other activities including the preservation of natural vegetation. They put forward propositions that in those days were not fashionable such as mechanisms to assist fencing out native vegetation, fencing out areas on private land that have significance for water conservation and a whole range of other things. It is not often that people who are involved in this get recognition for their services. I congratulate Elton Butcher for being recognised and for receiving the Order of Australia.

I well remember, soon after he jointed the Western Australian national soil conservation committee, seeing a car drive in when I was down on my own property. He had heard that I was planting trees through seeds. At that time, that was unique and considered to be one of those things that would not work and now that has all been proved wrong. Elton Butcher heard about this and had driven some 500 miles from his property at Pithara just to have a look at it being done in practice and to get a hands-on assessment of what was being done. That really epitomises the man and how he went about things. If he heard about an idea he wanted to see it and how it worked and make an assessment. He came back on a number of occasions to monitor progress through that particular period.

Lastly, I want to comment on the amendments to the Western Australian Soil Conservation Act 1991. The Hon. Mr Dick Old was the minister for agriculture and one of the principal people with a number of us who designed what is now the Landcare program of Australia. Elton Butcher made a magnificent contribution to soil conservation and the preservation of resources in this land and I salute him for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I want to give time to my colleague Senator Spindler. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The recommendations in the Industry Commission report entitled Impediments to regional industry adjustment are a mixed bag. First of all, I will address the points which I think are detrimental to regional development in Australia. The report argues the need for greater regional flexibility in unit labour costs and greater flexibility in wages and work practices based on less restrictive conditions on workplace agreements. The report argues that this does not mean regional wage cuts. What does it do if it does not do that precisely? It clearly seems to imply that people in regional areas should earn less than people in metropolitan areas.

PARA.TAB: The next matter that is greatly objected to is where the closure or downgrading of social infrastructure facilities within regions is contemplated. The report says, `Communities should be given the option of contributing directly to maintain facilities.' So not only should people in regions earn less money, but also they should pay more for the community facilities that people in metropolitan areas enjoy at a lower cost or free.

Finally, the report says that, where infrastructure provisions and delivery costs vary between locations, that should be reflected in different prices rather than masked by uniform prices. In other words, since it will cost more to provide services in regions, these costs should be reflected in the prices that people in regional communities pay. If it costs $13,000 to have a telephone connected—and in some remote areas that would be the case—the report suggests that that should be the price that people in regional areas should pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely disgusting!

—It is absolutely disgusting, as Senator Woodley says. I believe that we as a community must make up our minds: do we want people in regional areas; do we want people in rural Australia? France, Germany and the United States have made up their minds that they want a rural community. Those countries have made sure, by whatever means, be it trade measures, be it industry measures, be it community services, that they have vibrant and viable community in regional areas.

PARA.TAB: The report also points to some things that should be done to contribute to that. The report suggests that the Commonwealth should introduce income tax zone rebates designed to compensate residents of regions for lack of government services. That is fine. It suggests more transparency in, and better coordination of, decisions on regional infrastructure provisions, and that is fine too. Clearly, we need to know what we need to provide in regions.

The commission also considers that where governments seek to sustain populations in particular regions we should do so by improving regional infrastructure. Of course we must. We must take the range of measures which the Australian Democrats set down both in the budget proposals and in the paper that I published last Sunday as a challenge to the government in the white paper to do precisely that—to preserve our regional communities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 January 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What changes are proposed to the COP.
(2) Is the current system working effectively in all States and Territories and why is it to be changed.
(3) Have the Director of Counselling and VVCS staff in all States and Territories been consulted about the changes.
(4) Were the proposed changes requested by the Vietnam veterans organisations or the clients of the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Country Outreach Program (COP) is the service delivery model adopted by the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS) in 1988 to provide counselling and support services to country veterans and their dependants. It was proposed by the Waterhouse Committee of Review in 1983 and recommended in 1988 by the Evatt Royal Commission and by the House of Representatives Committee on Community Affairs "After the March" report. These recommendations were endorsed by the National Advisory Committee (NAC) on the VVCS at its meeting in December 1988.

The development of country outreach services is in line with the Government's commitment to ensuring better access, integration and availability of services to country veterans and their dependants. In the 1993-94 Budget, the Government approved funding for six COP co-ordinators to expand the program and allow veterans to have access to more effective counselling support right across Australia.

(2) The use of contract counsellors in non-metropolitan areas has improved the access and availability of counselling services. The COP has provided more accessible services to non-metropolitan veterans and their families but requires further development. The network of approved counsellors in non-metropolitan regions needs to be expanded to areas currently with no contract counsellors or area representatives, or where there are too few to meet the existing and new demands for services.

(3) Yes, the changes were discussed at a conference for Directors of Counselling and were the focus of a special workshop to discuss the changes in detail. There will be a staged approach to implementing the changes which will involve further detailed discussions with the Directors of Counselling.

(4) The changes were considered necessary to implement fully the recommendation of the "After the March" report which had input from the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia and clients of the service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 8 February 1994 that the department had examined the effects of introducing income splitting for tax purposes between couples with dependent children:
(1) When was the analysis conducted.
(2) Who authorised the analysis.
(3) How much did the analysis cost.
(4) Will the Minister undertake to table the results of the analysis.
(5) Is the department undertaking any further studies on the effects of tax policy changes on Australian families.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The analysis was conducted on 2 February 1994.
(2) The analysis was authorised by the Minister for Social Security.

(3) The cost of the analysis in salary dollars was approximately $100.00. This marginal cost excludes the cost of computer time and the cost of constructing the original computer model utilised to conduct the analysis.
(4) Yes. (Note: The analysis relates to couples with and without dependent children).

(5) At present no further specific studies are being conducted. However, Costings and Modelling Unit within the Department of Social Security has in the past frequently monitored the interactions between the taxation system and the incomes of

ANSWER.PARA: Australian families and will continue to do so as the need arises.

PARA.TAB: Comparison between the current tax liability and the tax liability incurred if the unit's income is split 50/50 between head and spouse (for married couples).

ANSWER.PARA: Increased Tax No Change to Decreased Tax
Increased Tax No Change Decreased Tax

PARA.TAB: (i) No change to tax liability has been recorded when the absolute change to tax liability is less than $1 p.a.
(ii) After the unit's taxable income has been split 50/50 between the head and spouse the Dependent Spouse, Pension and Allowee Rebates have been removed.
(iii) The increased tax liability for families in the $45,000 to $65,000 taxable income range is due to the loss of the Low Income Rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Maralinga nuclear test site:
(1) What is the precise amount that the United Kingdom has agreed to pay to Australia for the clean-up of the site.
(2) What are the details of the operation to be conducted to clean up and restore the site.
(3) What consultation, if any, was or is to be conducted with the Aboriginal custodians of the site.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The British Government has agreed to pay 20 million pounds sterling in settlement of Australia's claims concerning the British nuclear test program in Australia.

(2) The Government's preferred rehabilitation option was selected from the Range of options presented in the Report of the Technical Assessment Group (TAG), Rehabilitation of Former Nuclear Test Sites In Australia, Australian Government Publishing Service 1990. This option corresponds broadly with TAG option 6(c) and includes burial of soil from seriously contaminated sites, erecting boundary markers around more lightly contaminated areas and treatment of plutonium contaminated burial pits.

(3) There has been extensive consultation with Aboriginal representatives at Ministerial level and by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy concerning the test sites. Aboriginal people with an interest in the Maralinga region were represented on a Consultative Group established in 1986 as a forum for discussion of all matters concerning rehabilitation of the test sites including the TAG Study Program and the TAG Report. Their continued representation has been sought on the Group which has been reconvened to address the clean-up phase of the project.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 22 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Queensland Government sought matching funding from the Commonwealth Government for the cost of acquiring the property `Starcke' in far north Queensland from Mr George Quaid?
(2) Is the `Starcke' property separated from the coast by a strip of land between 400 and 1000 metres wide; if so, would any development be permitted on this strip of land?
(3) Has the Minister seen advice obtained by the Queensland Government from Mr James Douglas QC?
(4) Has the Minister seen the advice obtained for the Wilderness Society from Mr John Greenwood QC?
(5) Is the Minister satisfied that `Starcke' was not acquired or held by George Quaid holdings in evasion of or by fraud upon the Land Act of the State of Queensland?

(6) In a letter to a prospective buyer of `Starcke', did Mr Quaid state that the land has been held by his company since 1971 `as a future land bank for eco-tourism or eventual residential development' and that `the company runs a token herd of 1000 cattle to offset the annual holding costs'?
(7) Did this letter mention the `lack of maintenance of the leased land since the company gained the lease'?

(8) In order to establish the facts surrounding the `Starcke' case, and in order to settle the matter of fair compensation for any acquisition of the land by government in a cost effective manner, will the Minister request than an inquiry be held to establish the land's true value?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The Starcke leasehold and freehold lands are separated from the high water mark by an esplanade gazetted under the Queensland Beach Protection Act 1968. Development of the esplanade is subject to the provisions of this legislation.
(3) No. The Queensland Government has not publicly released this advice. My Department has sought a copy of the advice from Queensland.
(4) Yes. The advice was tabled in the Senate on 23 February 1994.
(5) I will be in a position to reach a conclusion on this matter when I have received and considered relevant legal advice.
(6) A copy of a letter purporting to be by Mr Quaid, and made publicly available by the Wilderness Society under FOI legislation, includes the above statement.

(8) It is the responsibility of the Queensland Government to establish the facts relating to the property. Any action by the Commonwealth Government will be in light of advice received from the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth's assessment of that advice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the donation to the Mitchell Library, Sydney, through the Taxation Incentives Scheme for the Arts, of a photographic portrait of colonial doctor, William Bland, which is believed to be the oldest surviving Australian photograph:
(1) When was the Taxation Incentives Scheme set up.
(2) What level of incentives are offered for the donation of art.
(3) How many donations have been made and which organisations received the works.
(4) What is the estimated commercial value of major donations.
(5) Who donated the artworks and what benefits did they receive under the Tax Incentives Scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Taxation Incentives for the Arts (TIA) Scheme was announced in the 1977-78 Budget speech in the Federal Parliament. It was trialled over a three year period and came into permanent operation on 1 January 1981.

(2) Donors are entitled to claim a tax deduction for the market value of their donation. The value is established by obtaining at least two valuations from valuers approved for the purpose of the TIA Scheme.

(3) Since the inception of the TIA Scheme, there have been approximately 14,000 items and over 2,000 collections gifted through the Scheme. It is not possible to provide details of all recipient public collecting institutions. However, a recent analysis over an 18 month period indicated that 39% of donations went to art galleries, 34% to libraries and 27% to museums.

(4) Details of the commercial value of individual major donations are not publicly available as this would breach the privacy requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, to date, donations to a total value of $104 million have been made through the Scheme.
(5) This information is also subject to the privacy requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act and therefore details cannot be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) elected to use "the Star of Vergina", an ancient Greek symbol belonging to the ancient Greek dynasty of Philip of Macedonia, as its flag.
(2) What effect will this have on FYROM's relationship with neighbouring countries.
(3) Has the Minister expressed disappointment over the FYROM's decision to use "the Star of Vergina" as its flag.

(4) Is the Minister aware that maps are being produced and distributed within the FYROM and even in Australia by members of the Yugoslav community which show northern Greece as part of FYROM: if so, has the Minister raised the issue at the United Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Parliament of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) adopted the FYROM's current national flag, which features the "Star of Vergina", on 11 August 1992 following consideration by its Constitutional Commission and negotiations between the main political parties.
(2) One of the FYROM's neighbours, Greece, has objected to the use by the FYROM of that symbol, claiming that it is a Greek symbol.

(3) In my statement of 15 February 1994 announcing recognition of the FYROM, I said that negotiations between Greece and the FYROM on the `name' and associated issues "would be much assisted by the Government in Skopje ceasing to use the "Star of Vergina" symbol on the FYROM's flag. . . " and urged the Government of the FYROM "to act accordingly". In that statement I

ANSWER.PARA: also noted that "our early agreement to the opening of a Consulate would be much assisted by a statement on the public record by the Government of the FYROM that it is prepared to act immediately, or at least as soon as the necessary legislative majority is achievable to change the country's flag."

PARA.TAB: (4) I am aware that maps are being produced and distributed within the FYROM and even in Australia showing northern Greece as part of the FYROM. In my statements of 15 February and 14 March I emphasised the point that it would be a most helpful step if the continued proliferation of offensive irredentist propaganda was curbed. In the latter statement I made specific reference to maps of "Greater Macedonia". The United Nations is already fully engaged in efforts to settle differences between Athens and Skopje. The UN Secretary-General's Special Representative, Cyrus Vance, has been consulting with both parties since April 1993 with the objective of resolving outstanding issues between the two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 2 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports of the leakage of contaminated waste water from the Roxby Downs uranium mine's tailing dam:

(1) Has around 5 million cubic metres of processed waste water seeped into the underground water table; if so, on what date did Western Mining Corporation inform the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency or the Minister about the seepage from the tailings dam.
(2) Is it a fact that the only ongoing monitoring of the dam is carried out by Western Mining Corporation and that there is no regular monitoring by State or Federal Government departments.
(3) Is the Government considering extending the function of the Office of the Supervising Scientist or creating a similar position to monitor the operations of this mine; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Advice from Western Mining Corporation is that on initial estimates, the local water table at the mine has risen by up to 5 million cubic metres, believed to be due to seepage from the mine's tailings dam; samples from the monitoring bores show no contamination by dissolved metals or radioactivity above natural background levels and no acidity. A cording to the 15 February 1994 Hansard of the South Australian Parliament, on 20 August 1993 results of studies by the Corporation pointed to the possibility that the tailings dam at the Olympic Dam minesite at Roxby Downs could be leaking. However it was not until 11 February 1994, that senior officials from the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency were informed by telephone by the South Australian Department of Mines and Energy of seepage from the mine's tailings retention system. This was followed on 14 February 1994 by direct advice from the Corporation to the Secretary of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and a Western Mining Corporation Olympic Dam Operations media release. The Corporation did not inform the former Minister directly.

(2) Statutory obligations for supervision and monitoring of operations of the mine rest entirely with the South Australian Government. Under the Roxby Downs (Indenture Ratification) Act 1982, a three year programme for the protection, management and rehabilitation (if appropriate) of the environment (including arrangements for monitoring) is required to be submitted to the South Australian Minister responsible. According to the Corporation, the company, independent experts and state authorities have been monitoring the local water table since operations began in 1988.

(3) It is recognised that current disclosure and reporting requirements have not been adequate and officials are currently considering options for improving arrangements. No decision has been made as a result of the announcement of the seepage about the possible involvement of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region in monitoring the operations of the Olympic Dam mine.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 2 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the termination by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of the VLW shortwave service in Western Australia:
(1) What alternative technologies are available to deliver the services previously carried by the VLW system.
(2) Which parts of Western Australia are covered by each of these alternative technologies.
(3) What reception equipment is required to pick up services delivered by each of these technologies.
(4) What is the cost of this reception equipment in each case.
(5) Which of the above technologies are suited to mobile reception, for example, as required by seafarers, mineral exploration crews, and pastoralists.
(6) Is it technically feasible to use existing shortwave broadcasting transmitters at Carnarvon, Derby and Hedland to broadcast services previously carried by VLW; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the National Transmission Agency:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are five possible delivery technologies currently available:
Satellite
High Frequency (HF)
High Frequency Shower
Medium Frequency (MF) AM
Very High Frequency (VHF) FM

(2) The HACBSS (Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service) delivered by OPTUS satellite has been available throughout WA since 1987 for the delivery of ABC-TV, Radio National and Regional Radio. ABC Classic FM is also available by this means.
With the closure of VLW there is no transmission of ABC Radio services available on HF in WA.

The HF Shower is used only in the Northern Territory. Some parts of eastern WA may be able to receive it but it is not designed to serve WA. It is an expensive method of radio broadcasting and for this reason rarely used.

The Second Regional Radio Network (SRRN) now provides many people throughout regional WA with radio services previously only received on HACBSS or VLW. It was always intended that VLW service would be closed down with the introduction of the HACBSS satellite and expansion of SRRN.

MF transmissions cover most of the population of WA. NTA transmitters are at Albany, Bridgetown, Broome, Busselton, Carnarvon, Dalwallinu, Esperance, Exmouth, Kalgoorlie, Kununurra, Manjimup, Northam, Pannawonica, Paraburdoo, Perth, Port Hedland, Tom Price, Wagin and Wyndham.

VHF-FM also covers much of the population of WA. NTA transmitters are at: Argyle Mine, Augusta, Broome, Bunbury, Carnarvon, Central Agricultural (Mawson), Cue, Dampier, Denham, Derby, Eneabba, Esperance, Exmouth, Fitzroy Crossing, Geraldton, Halls Creek, Jurien, Kalbarri, Kalgoorlie, Karratha, Koolan Island, Kununurra, Laverton, Leeman, Leonora, Marble Bar, Meekatharra, Menzies, Merredin, Mt Magnet, Nannup, Newman, Norseman, Onslow, Pannawonica, Paraburdoo, Perth, Port Hedland, Ravensthorpe, Salmon Gums, Southern Agricultural (Mt Barker), Southern Cross, Tom Price, Wyndham and Yalgoo.

In addition, licenced self-help rebroadcasting facilities are located at Blackstone, Bow River Mine, Darlot, Golden Grove, Goldsworthy, Jamieson, Leinster, Mt Whaleback, Nullagine, Shay Gap, Tjirrkarli, Tom Price Mine, Warakurna, Warburton, Wiluna, Yandicoogina and Yiyili.

Facilities provided under the Broadcasting for Remote Aboriginal Communities Scheme (BRACS) are located at Balgo, Beagle Bay, Djarindjin, Jigalong, Kalumburu, Kiwirrkurra, Langrange, Looma, Oombulgurri, Tjukurla, Warmun, Wingellina, Yandeyarra and Yungngora.
(3) Satellite—Satellite receiver and B-MAC decoder (homesteads will already have these), plus audio system—eg. a Hi-Fi system.
High Frequency—Shortwave receiver, preferably with an external antenna.
MF Radio Transmissions—an MF AM radio receiver.
VHF-FM—an FM radio receiver.
(4) Satellite Receiving System providing access to 2 TV services and 3-4 radio services—typically $2500-$3000.
Shortwave Radio—typically $80-$400 depending on quality, technology employed, and individual preference.
MF Radio—typically $20-$250 depending on quality and individual preference.
VHF-FM—typically $20-$250 depending on quality and individual preference.

(5) MF radio is most suitable for mobile reception. However sufficient MF stations could not be established to reach all of the Australian land mass without significant cost outlays. HF can cover large areas but is less reliable and expensive to establish and maintain.

(6) Existing shortwave transmitters at Carnarvon currently broadcast Radio Australia programs 24 hours per day. The existing antennas are optimised for transmissions to overseas target areas and would not be suitable for domestic shortwave broadcasting as they are presently positioned. The possible use of transmitters at Carnarvon for domestic shortwave broadcasting would require extensive work and Carnarvon may not be the best site for such a purpose.
There are no national broadcasting shortwave transmitters at either Derby or Port Hedland.

The ABC has negotiated with the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) of Australia to carry cyclone warnings and daily News Bulletins on its transmitters at Port Hedland, Derby, Carnarvon and Meekatharra. The coverage of the RFDS service is in the areas of north western Australia where the majority of complaints have arisen from listeners to the previous VLW service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Technology in Government Committee formed through the Prime Minister's office in 1987:
(1) What is the background to the committee's formation and the involvement of the Prime Minister's office.
(2) Is the Prime Minister's office still involved either directly or indirectly with the committee; if so, how.
(3) What is the committee's charter and how are they appointed.
(4) Who are the members of the committee and how are they appointed.
(5) Is the committee a Government body.
(6) To whom is the committee responsible.
(7) Are any Federal Government departments involved either directly or indirectly with the committee; if so, what is the extent of that involvement.
(8) Has the committee received any funding from the Federal Government; if so, when and what is the total of that funding.
(9) Does the committee issue any reports and what documentation is available about its work.
(10) What success has the committee had in achieving its objectives.
(11) Has the work of the committee been evaluated at any time; if so, is this information available.
(12) Has the Minister, his predecessor (Mr Griffiths), or his junior Minister (Senator Schacht) met recently with any member of the committee or its executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As the Technology in Government Committee is not a Government body, information in relation to the questions was sought from the committee.

(1) The Chairman of the Technology in Government Committee has advised that the disbanding of the Productivity Promotion Council was the catalyst for the committee's formation in 1986. The proposal was forwarded to the Prime Minister's Office which lent its support to the committee's formation.
(2) The committee provides information on its activities to the Prime Minister's office on an ongoing basis. The Prime Minister's Office has provided letters of support for committee activities.
(3) The charter of the committee is attached.
There are twenty positions available on the committee and these are filled on a needs basis depending on the projects being undertaken at the time.
(4) The current membership of the committee is:
Mr Colin Archer
Mr Michael Matchett
Mrs Megan Alexander
Mr Roger Price
Mr Ron Wilson
Professor Brian Garner
Mr David Connelly
Mr John Gardner
The committee identifies organisations and individuals who it considers could make a contribution to the work of the committee.
(6) The committee is responsible for its own activities in line with its charter.

(7) Federal Government departments are indirectly involved with the committee through participation in its activities, for example, attendance at the Government Technology Conferences and Exhibitions, and nominations for the Government Technology Productivity Awards.

(9) The committee publishes the Government Technology Guide, a magazine with articles and editorial on issues affecting Government Technology users. It also produces general documentation relating to its activities, for example, information on forthcoming conferences and exhibitions.

(10) The committee has advised that the Government Technology Productivity Awards (developed by the Committee) have proven successful in promoting the achievements of government departments across Australia.
The committee has also instituted an annual National Technology in Government Conference.
This forum looks at the issues associated with the use of technology in Government and provides other governments both here and overseas with relevant information.

An exhibition of new technology products and services is also held in Canberra each year which brings together government managers from the three tiers of government to discuss issues relating to improving productivity through the use of technology.

(11)The committee has advised that it carries out assessments of its activities on an ongoing basis and provides information about its work in the Government Technology Guide, through media press releases and through direct contact with government and industry.
All Government Technology Guides are held in the National Library and associated State libraries. Media releases and other documentation are available depending on their age and/or relevance.
Attachment

PARA.EMPHASIS: The objectives of the committee are to:

PARA.TAB: .promote the productive use of technology by governments across Australia
.further the exchange of information about computer and telecommunications technology, and the benefits to be derived from its use amongst industry and government
.assist and promote activities aimed at improving Australia's productivity performance
.liaise with productivity organisations and disseminate information about their activities to the government community
.facilitate the development of export markets by international promotion of the use of technology
.facilitate the development of export markets by the three tiers of government in Australia
.encourage investment in Australian technology industries through the promotion of the use of technology across the three tiers of government

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to paragraph (3) of the answer to question on notice no. 834 (Senate Hansard, 28 February 1994, page 1143) relating to the Parliamentary network, in which reference is made to the cost of providing facilities for a nationally networked Parliamentary Broadcast Service and it is suggested that the cost is approximately $26.5 million:
(1) Has there been a recent investigation into whether or not the Parliamentary Broadcast Service should be extended to cover regional stations; if so, please provide details.

(2) In a site where the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and/or the National Transmission Agency have aerials and other transmission facilities, what would be the approximate cost of establishing parliamentary broadcast transmission facilities at that site.

(3) Have any surveys been done to indicate the audience of the Parliamentary Broadcast Service in places where it currently exists; if so, please provide details and compare that audience with the audience for ABC regional transmissions, ABC National Radio Network, ABC FM, SBS Radio and Triple J radio.
(4) Are there current surveys of the viewing audience for parliamentary question time and for the parliamentary program `Order in the House'; if so, please provide details.
(5) Are any such survey figures broken up into regional and metropolitan areas; if so, please provide details.
(6) Once the capital works establishing transmission facilities are in place, what would be the annual cost of maintaining any single transmission site.
(7) Is there any annual report for the Parliamentary Broadcast Service; if so, please provide a copy.
(8) Does the Parliamentary Broadcast Service's budget figure in the annual report of other agencies; if so, please provide a copy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the National Transmission Agency, to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (2) The National Transmission Agency provides transmission facilities for ABC and SBS radio and television services and the current Parliamentary Broadcasting service. These facilities differ enormously in the coverage which they provide (from a few hundred to several million people), and in the complexity and cost of their construction.

The cost of adding to existing facilities in order to provide a parliamentary broadcasting service at individual sites would also vary widely, depending upon such factors as the location of the facility, the size of the transmitter and its power requirements, and the need to modify the existing facility.

Assuming that frequency modulation (FM) transmission facilities were employed, capital costs could vary between something less than $50,000 and $1 million. For a major regional site at which infrastructure exists with capacity to transmit an additional program service, the cost would be approximately $300,000.
(3) Surveys have not been conducted by the ABC on the size of the audience for the Parliamentary Broadcast service and this information is not available from AGB:McNair ratings service.

(4) A copy of extensive statistical returns on the average audience for the live and replay telecast of Parliamentary Question Time and Order in the House has been provided separately to the honourable senator.

(5) A copy of the details of audience reach by demographics over a twelve week period for each of the five cities has been provided separately to the honourable senator. ABC Television does not currently purchase regional data.

(6) As explained in the answer to part (2), transmission facilities differ enormously in cost and complexity. The additional cost of operating and maintaining additional transmission facilities, could range from $30,000 to $150,000 per annum per site.

(7) Annual reporting for the Parliamentary Broadcast Network is incorporated in the Department of the Parliament Reporting Staff's (DPRS) Annual Report. A copy of the 1992-93 Annual Report for the DPRS has been provided separately to the honourable senator.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Industries and Energy: Electoral Profiles

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department, or any of its agencies produce electoral profiles (or other like documents) outlining relevant programs, services or other forms of assistance provided in individual federal electorates; if so, when were these electoral profiles (or other like documents) first produced and how frequently are they produced?
(2) Is a copy of these electoral profiles (or other like documents) provided to the Parliamentary Library; if not, why not?
(3) Please provide a copy of the most up-to-date edition of each of these electoral profiles (or other like documents) for all federal electorates to the Parliamentary Library.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Information on National Landcare Program (NLP) applications for project funding is held in a number of computer readable forms which are capable cf producing information by electorate. The database is used to prepare letters which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has sent to members of the House of Representatives informing them of the projects funded by the NLP or its predecessors in their electorates. Similar letters have been sent to Government Senators informing them of projects in electorates in which they are interested.
Letters have been sent to parliamentarians at the time of the Budget informing them of funding for water projects since about 1986 and for soil conservation projects since 1991.

Apart from this the Department and its agencies use the Parliamentary Stack (produced by the Parliament) when electoral profiles are required. There are no other databases on Departmental programs, services and other forms of assistance organised by federal electorates.

Information on Commonwealth assistance in specific individual federal electorates is prepared, where possible, in response to individual requests from members of Parliament and the public. It is not always possible to provide totally accurate information as the data is not collected on an electorate basis and cannot always be successfully broken down in this way. Some profiles are prepared approximately matching electoral boundaries which have been extracted from the ABS Integrated Regional Data Base using aggregates of the ABS Statistical Local Area to approximate electoral areas.

(2) In the case of Landcare, water and soil conservation funding, because all relevant members are personally advised, it has not been considered necessary to provide copies of correspondence between the Minister and Members of Parliament to the Parliamentary Library.
Responses to individual briefing requests are not provided to the Parliamentary Library.
(3) A copy of the list of NLP projects funded in the 1993-94 financial year will be provided to the Parliamentary Library. All electorates containing NLP projects are included in this list.

(2) Has the corporation since become insolvent and been placed under administration; if so, who is the liquidator or receiver, as is appropriate.
(3) What audits or financial investigations have been conducted into the corporation by or on behalf of ATSIC or the department and what are the details of any such investigation.
(4) What is the shortfall to creditors of the corporation.
(5) Has any of the directors or senior managers of the corporation applied to ATSIC for the payment of termination benefits otherwise payable by the corporation.

(6) Is it the case that directors and senior managers of the corporation are limited in the amount of termination and other benefits they are entitled to recover as ordinary unsecured creditors of the corporation by virtue of their being prescribed persons under the corporations law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The QED Legal Service received ATSIC funding in the following financial years:
1990/91—$672,391—operations costs
1990/91—$3,045—computer training
1990/91—$3,084—crime prevention forum
1991/92—$419,536—operations costs

(2) On 16 September 1993, by order of the Federal Court in Brisbane, the corporation was placed under the administration of appointed liquidators, Mr Ivor Worrell, of Worrell Whitehill, Chartered Accountants, Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services, upon notice, on 15 March 1994:

(1) What formulas and figures were used for allocating specific grants to each council to demonstrate in each instance how the actual figure of the grant was calculated by reference to the components that were taken into account to arrive at the final figure.

(2) Do the requirements of the program provide that once an amount had been determined for a particular council, it was then entirely up to the council to determine on what projects that total sum was spent.
(3) Please detail instances where councils had submitted projects up to the total value of the grant made to them, but these projects were rejected by the State Advisory Committee.

(4) Given that the Guidelines for Applicants for the Local Capital Works Program indicated that once State Advisory Committees had assessed applications from councils, the proposals were sent to the Commonwealth Office of Local Government in Canberra for final approval by Commonwealth Ministers, please indicate and identify those proposals submitted by State Advisory Committees that did not receive final approval by Commonwealth Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Guidelines for the Local Capital Works Program which were available from the time the program was announced in combination with the paper Area Selection and Funding Distribution Methodology contain the answer to this question. I refer the honourable senator to Appendices 1 and 5 of the December 1993 Evaluation of the Administration of the Local Capital Works Program.

(2) No. All eligible councils submitted proposed projects to the level of their total program allocation to State Advisory Committees for their consideration and those Committees in turn made recommendations for approval to Commonwealth Ministers. If a State Advisory Committee had concerns about a proposed project, the Committee asked the council to modify that proposal or submit another proposal.

(3) As part of the development of the Local Capital Works Program, the Commonwealth funded facilitators in State Local Government Associations to liaise with councils to develop project proposals. In many cases draft project proposals were discussed and modified before they were put to State Advisory Committees.
In the case of Queensland the following project proposals were formally rejected by the State Advisory Committee because they did not meet Commonwealth funding criteria:
Hervey Bay—Office Procedures Training Program ($90,000 Commonwealth grant requested);
Beaudesert—Asset Management Water and Sewerage Department ($25,000 Commonwealth grant requested);
Beaudesert—Digital Capture of Council Minutes for Text Retrieval System ($50,000 Commonwealth grant requested);
Beaudesert—Health Research and Records Upgrade ($25,000 Commonwealth grant requested);
Gold Coast—Geographical Information System ($990,000 Commonwealth grant requested); and
Gold Coast—Pavement Management System ($81,000 Commonwealth grant requested).

(4) The general procedure adopted was that Commonwealth Ministers considered projects recommended for approval by State Advisory Committees. In Queensland no projects recommended for approval by the State Advisory Committee were rejected by Commonwealth Ministers.

However, two project proposals from the Gold Coast Council which were rejected by the Queensland State Advisory Committee, were referred to Commonwealth Ministers at the council's insistence. Ministers confirmed the Committee's rejection of the two proposals. The projects, neither of which met program guidelines, were:
Pavement Management System ($81,000): the project involved capturing and entering data into a pavement management system; and
Geographical Information System ($990,000): the project involved building a data base for management of council infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) CSL Limited received from the Commonwealth $120,000 over the three years to 30 June 1992 for research and development of an antivenom for jack jumper ant bite.
(2) The number on the register of names of people needing jack jumper ant antivenom, on a State-by-State basis, is as follows:
Tasmania—81
New South Wales—16
Victoria—207
Queensland—4
South Australia—22
Western Australia—0
ACT—6
Total—336

(3) and (4) Under commercial arrangements applying to CSL since its corporatisation in 1990, CSL would not be expected to undertake research in fields which could not be justified on commercial grounds. CSL continued jack jumper ant antivenom research after Commonwealth funding ceased in June 1992, but following a reappraisal of progress against commercial criteria, the Company has now decided to discontinue the research work from the end of 1993-94.

CSL has arranged the relocation of antivenom research to a major academic institute. An announcement will be made to that effect in the near future. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the department calculating rates of returns on investments in the Meridian Investment Trust for income testing purposes by using the list price of the trust rather than the last sale price on the first day of its issue; if so, what is the legislative basis for using this method of calculating rates of return on investments in the Meridian Investment Trust and what is the rationale for using the list price of the trust rather than the last sale price on the first day of issue.
(2) In relation to which, if any, other listed securities, and listed managed investments does the department use the list price rather than the last sale price on the first day of issue.
(3) In the current market in relation to property trusts, what would be the likely impact on pension entitlement of using the list price rather than the last sale price on the first day of issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

The Meridian Investment Trust (MIT) is treated as a managed investment. For social security income test purposes, managed investments acquired after 9 September 1988 (whether listed on the stock exchange or not) have income assessed at a rate of return based upon the performance of the investment over the previous 12 months, taking account of changes in capital value and any income distributions.

MIT (formerly Estate Mortgage) listed on 16 December 1993. In the period leading up to listing, the Estate Mortgage trusts were suspended from trading. Hence, there was no past performance data at the date of listing.

The listing of MIT involved the merger of the former Estate Mortgage trusts. The circumstances of the merger meant that the merged products were not new products for assessment purposes. However, as there was no performance data for the products for the previous 12 months, the net asset backing of a unit in the MIT ($1.00 per unit) was used as the start point for assessment purposes from 16 December 1993.
The last sale price on the first day of listing was not used as the start point because the merged units were not considered to be a new investment product.

(2) In general, the last sale price on the first day of listing is used for any new share or managed investment product. Where listing involves the continuation of an existing managed investment product, no new product is created and the calculation of the rate of return is not affected directly by the process of listing, except to the extent that it affects the current price of the listed product.

(3) For new investments that have existed for less than 12 months, the impact on pension entitlement of using the list price rather than the sale price on the first day of listing for calculating the rate of return would depend on:
the list price;
the sale price on the first day of listing; and
the sale price at the current point in time of assessment.
Where the current sale price is higher than either the list price or the sale price on the first day of listing, the general impact would be:
to increase the income assessed (and reduce pension entitlement) where the list price was lower than the price at the end of the first day of listing; and
to decrease the income assessed (and increase pension entitlement) where the list price was higher than the price at the end of the first day of listing.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the purpose and charter of operation of Australian Education Centres, and when were they established.
(2) What consultations were held, and with whom, in relation to the department's examination of options to restructure the centres.
(3) Has the Board of the Australian International Education Foundation been appointed; if so, who has been appointed and what organisation does each member represent.
(4) What is the mechanism by which industry will contribute operating funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The purpose of the Australian Education Centres (AECs) is to provide international students with information and advice about study in Australia.
The charter of operation of the AECs is:
(1) Operate AECs at agreed locations so as to facilitate the marketing activities of Australian education and training institutions.
(2) Provide the following services:
(a) an accessible "shopfront" for persons interested in Australian education;
(b) accurate and current information on courses offered by Australian institutions;
(c) educational counselling and advisory services;
(d) liaison with local media and educational bodies; and
(e) processing of student applications for Australian educational institutions, and provision of other services to institutions on a fee-for-service basis.
The AECs were established during the period March to July 1990.

(2) The Department consulted the National Consultative Committee on International Education and Training Services (membership is at Attachment A), managers and staff of AECs and education providers who responded to a press advertisement calling for submissions on the Review of AECs.
(4) The industry will contribute operating funds through subscriptions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 28th March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice No. 281 (Senate Hansard 17 August 1993, page 141):
(1) Have the Beeliar Wetlands in Western Australia now been interim listed on the Register of the National Estate by the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC); if not, why not.
(2) When were the Beeliar Wetlands nominated for inclusion on the Register of the National Estate.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the WA Department of Planning and Urban Development finalised its proposals for the boundaries of the Beeliar Regional Park nearly 2 years ago.
(4) If the wetlands have not been listed, are delays of this magnitude a common occurrence, and are there any special reasons for such a lengthy delay.
(5) Do similar reasons apply to the delay in listing the Leda and Ellenbrook areas and the bushland at Jandakot and Perth airports.
(6) How many nominations received by the AHC have been waiting for listing for more than 10 years.
(7) Is the AHC required to process nominations within any specified time frame; if not, why not.
(8) Has the Minister taken any action to ensure that the AHC processes nominations for the Register of the National Estate within a reasonable time frame; if not, why not.
(9) What procedures are in place to ensure that political interference by State government authorities does not impede the listing process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. However, on 11 April 1994, the Australian Heritage Commission decided to enter the Beeliar Wetlands in the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate. Listing is scheduled for the next gazettal notice at the end of this year.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Australian Heritage Commission receives a large number of nominations and cannot process all nominations immediately. Priorities for assessment must be assigned, and these are based on whether the area is under threat, whether Commonwealth decisions are pending, or whether the area can be assessed as one of a suite of like places, or within a more comprehensive assessment of an entire region.

Processing of the Beeliar Wetlands has not been assigned a high priority because the area has at no stage been the subject of any Commonwealth decision, and the WA State Government has been moving towards the declaration of a Park over this area. The Beeliar Wetlands is a complex nomination. Investigation and validation of the claimed values, and selection of an appropriate boundary, has therefore been a complex and lengthy task.
(5) The priorities in assessing these places were determined according to the above guidelines.
Jandakot and Perth airports were placed on the Interim List on 17 November 1992.
The Commission decided on 8 February 1994 to enter Ellenbrook in the Interim List, and gazettal is scheduled for later this year.

While the Leda Area has not been subject to any Commonwealth decisions, the Commission is aware that the area is likely to be subject to development proposals, and for this reason has allocated priority to its assessment. If it is found to have national estate significance, interim listing would be most likely to occur at one of the two annual interim listings in 1995.

(6) Fifty nominations in Western Australia have been waiting for listing consideration for more than 10 years; of these three are natural environment places. In most cases these nominations have not been processed because of a lack of a sufficient level of information supplied by the nominator or otherwise available to the Commission.
(7) The Commission is not required to process nominations within any specified time. Nominations are not provided for in its Act. They are a mechanism adopted by the Commission.

(8) Although there is no requirement to process nominations in a set time frame, in 1988 under a previous Minister the Commission was provided with additional resources to help process the backlog of nominations. This has led to a reduction in the overall backlog by approximately 60%.
(9) The Commission is an independent statutory body. Its political independence is maintained through the appointment of independent Commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 30 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article in the Canberra Times on 11 March 1994 regarding the Government's program to reduce unleaded fuel usage and comments by leading British environmental scientist, Dr Roger Perry:

(1) (a) Is it a fact that changes in the levels of lead in people's blood have no correlation with the changing levels of lead in petrol; and (b) please detail the proof of any such correlation or non-correlation.

(2) (a) Is it a fact that the use of unleaded fuel in old motor vehicles risks a major rise in the incidence of leukemia due to increased emissions of benzene; (b) please explain the relationship between leukemia and benzene; and (c) please explain the benzene content of fuel and fuel emissions.

(3) (a) Is it a fact that the Government has spent millions of dollars in a campaign to encourage owners of old motor vehicles to use unleaded fuel; and (b) please outline the Government's program to encourage current users of leaded fuel in their motor vehicles to use unleaded fuel and the costs involved in this program.

(4) (a) Did the Federal Government take the health risks of unleaded fuel use in old cars into account before embarking on its program to encourage motorists to switch to unleaded fuel and increasing the fuel excise; and (b) please outline the health risks of using unleaded and leaded fuel in pre-1986 motor vehicles which were studied by the Government before embarking on this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A report "Reducing Lead Exposure in Australia, An Assessment of Impacts", prepared by the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology for the National Health and Medical Research Council cited studies conducted in the United States of America which showed a clear correlation between the level of lead in people's blood and the level of lead in fuel.

A major source of preventable lead pollution is generated by burning leaded petrol. It has been estimated that this contributes 90% of lead in air. Lead in air contributes to lead in dust, soil and water. Generally, where lead levels in petrol and the usage of leaded petrol have fallen, there is a reduction in blood lead levels.
(2) (a) In Australia no.
(b) Benzene is a known carcinogen which is strongly linked to the incidence of leukemia.

(c) Benzene content of crude oil is very low. It is formed in several refinery operations, the main source being catalytic reforming. In Australia benzene content of petrol is restricted to a maximum 5%.

(3) (a) and (b) The Government has spent 2.89 million dollars on a campaign designed to encourage owners of pre-1986 cars, which are able to use unleaded petrol, to do so. A list of cars able to use unleaded petrol was prepared with the cooperation of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries and the car companies and distributed widely through motoring and motor trade associations and the oil companies. Educational material was prepared for motor mechanics dealing with technical aspects of switching to unleaded petrol. An advertising campaign was run on television and in the newspapers and the oil companies assisted the campaign through service station displays, signs and promotions.
Additionally, educational material was prepared for medical professionals, home renovators and professional painters highlighting the risks associated with lead exposure.
(4) (a) There are no additional health risks because standard leaded petrol produced in Australia is essentially the same in benzene producing potential as leaded.

(b) The health risks associated with exposure to lead have been extensively examined and documented in Australia and overseas. They include impaired intellectual development in children, kidney damage and raised blood pressure. The following initiatives were undertaken in Australia to review the health effects of lead: Commonwealth and State health and environmental agencies jointly sponsored the "International Meeting on Non-Occupational Exposures to Lead" in Melbourne, October 1992. This meeting brought together Australian and international experts to discuss recent studies into health effects of lead.

The Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health commissioned the South Australian Health Commission to conduct a review of public exposure to lead in Australia. The Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology was also commissioned to prepare the report "Reducing Lead Exposure in Australia—An Assessment of Impacts and Risk Analysis of Economic and Environmental Impacts".

The findings were reviewed at the June and November 1993 meetings of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which recommended a goal for all Australians to achieve a blood lead level of less than 10 micrograms per decilitre, with 15 micrograms per decilitre to be achieved by 1998.

Strategies put in place by Commonwealth and State Governments to meet that goal should be sufficient to achieve a blood lead level of 10 micrograms per decilitre in 90% of children, aged 0-4 years, by 1998. A blood lead survey is being carried out later in 1994 to assess progress of the lead reduction program.

PARA.TAB: There are and have been a number of programs within my portfolio which provide or have provided general purpose and particular purpose grants to bodies for conservation or environmental purposes. Chief among these are general purpose grants made under the Program of Grants to Voluntary Conservation Organisations and particular purpose grants made under the National Estate Grants Program, Save the Bush Program and One Billion Trees Program.
